  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
Today, the investigation continues into the tragedy
  at Virginia Tech and, of course, our correspondents are on the scene covering
  every angle.
 
A picture of Cho Seung-Hui is slowly emerging: he was
  a solitary young man with few friends. But his bizarre behavior had been
  noticed – two women at Virginia Tech say they raised concerns in 2005
  about Cho’s repeated attempts to contact them. When can a school take
  steps against a student it suspects might someday cause harm? Cynthia Bowers will
  have the details.
 
The paper trail Cho left behind helps fill in the
  picture. Sharyn Alfonsi will report on Cho’s alarming creative writing
  pieces, the ranting note he left behind and the latest on the investigation
  into Monday’s massacre.
 
A significant part of that investigation hinges on
  forensic evidence, and some of that is locked inside the computer Cho owned
  and used. Technology correspondent Daniel Sieberg will report on how
  authorities are extracting information from the gunman’s hard drive.
 
Also, Thalia Assuras will have an emotional
  interview with a young woman who lives near the site of the first shooting
  Monday. It’s a dramatic account.
 
In other news, the Supreme Court upheld the
  country’s ban on certain abortions this morning. The justices ruled 5-4
  that the Partial Birth Abortion Ban Act that Congress passed and President
  Bush signed four yeas ago is constitutionally sound. Wyatt Andrews will have
  more on the decision. Our chief legal analyst, Andrew Cohen, will also weigh
  in on the implications of the decision.
 
Finally, it has been an extraordinarily deadly day
  in Baghdad,
  where more than 175 people were killed in a series of bombings – the
  worst day of violence since the American troop surge began a few months ago.
  Martin Seemungal will report.
 
I hope you’ll join us.
 




Katie Couric
